titlePart.text: MEASURING LENGTH, THICKNESS, OR SIMILAR LINEAR DIMENSIONS
MEASURING IRREGULARITIES OF SURFACES OR CONTOURS
titlePart.entryReference: measuring human body, see the relevant places, where such exist, e.g. , ,
tool-setting or drawing instruments not specially modified for measuring , , ,
combinations of measuring devices with writing-appliances
geodetical, nautical or aeronautical measuring, surveying, rangefinding
investigating particle size, investigating surface area of porous material
using radar, using sonar, using analogous systems employing other waves
measuring length or roll diameter of film in cameras or projectors
combinations of measuring devices with means for controlling or regulating
measuring elapsed travel of recording medium in recording and playback equipment, sensing diameter of record in autochange gramophones
means structurally associated with electric rotary current collectors for indicating brush wear
indicating consumption of electrodes in arc lamps

noteParagraph.text: Attention is drawn to the notes immediately following the class title ().

Measuring, by methods of general application, displacements, e.g. of the pointer of a measuring instrument, which are caused by variables of which the measurement is not covered by this sub-class, is dealt with in sub-class .

The groups of this sub-class are distinguished by the means of measurement which is of major importance. Thus the mere application of other means for giving a final indication does not affect the classification.
Machines operated on similar principles to the hand-held devices specified in this sub-class are classified with these devices.

titlePart.text: Measuring instruments characterised by the selection of material therefor
Instruments as specified in the sub-groups and characterised by the use of mechanical measuring means
Rulers or tapes with scales or marks for direct reading
Compasses, i.e. with a pair of pivoted arms
Bars, blocks, or strips in which the distance between a pair of faces is fixed, although it may be preadjustable, e.g. end measure, feeler strip
Ring or other apertured gauges, e.g. "go/no-go" gauge
Gauges with an open yoke and opposed faces, i.e. calipers, in which the internal distance between the faces is fixed, although it may be preadjustable
Plug gauges for internal dimensions with engaging surfaces which are at a fixed distance, although they may be preadjustable
Gauges for measuring angles or tapers, e.g. conical calipers
Measuring arrangements characterised by the use of mechanical means
titlePart.entryReference: instruments of the types covered by group per se

titlePart.text: for measuring length, width, or thickness

for measuring thickness, e.g. of sheet material
of objects while moving, e.g. cable
for measuring distance or clearance between spaced objects or spaced apertures
between a succession of regularly spaced objects or regularly spaced apertures, e.g. screw threads, stamp perforations
for measuring contours or curvatures, e.g. determining profile
for testing the alignment of axes
for testing the alignment of axes
for measuring roughness or irregularity of surfaces
for measuring the deformation in a solid, e.g. mechanical strain gauge
Measuring arrangements characterised by the use of electric or magnetic means

for measuring contours or curvatures, e.g. determining profile
for testing the alignment of axes
for testing the alignment of axes
for measuring roughness or irregularity of surfaces
Instruments as specified in the sub-groups and characterised by the use of optical measuring means
Optical projection comparators, e.g. for profile
Goniometers for measuring angles between surfaces, e.g. of crystals or prisms
Measuring arrangements characterised by the use of optical means

noteParagraph.text: Inventions covered by two or more of groups are classified in this group if no single other group can be selected as being predominantly applicable.
